The City of Calexico Water Treatment Plant is located at 545 Pierce Ave, Calexico CA 92231.

The City of Calexico has developed a Risk Management Plan to address California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Sections 2735-2785).  City of Calexico is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring Community.  City of Calexico staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor its facility to provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using chlorine for water treatment.  Chlorine plays an important role in water treatment and water reclamation, enabling everyone to lead healthier lives.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The facility has a long-standing commitment to its workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the chlorine system. The facility?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The chlorine system at the City of Calexico's Water Treatment Plant is used for the treatment of water prior to pumping into the City's water supply pipelines.

The Chlorine Room stores a total of ten (10) containers. The chlorine containers are placed on weight scales lined up side-by-side connected to the chlorine system. Normally only two (2) of the chlorine containers are kept online. The containers are connected by a yoke and adapter with new lead gaskets.

Chlorine gas under pressure flows from the online container through a vacuum regulator. The vacuum regulators reduce the chlorine pressure to a vacuum. The chlorine gas is suctioned out of the containers using vacuum pressure generated by a fl

ow of pumped water.

Three gaseous chlorinators are installed in the enclosed room adjacent to the chlorine containers. The chlorinators meter and inject gaseous chlorine into the raw water supply as it enters the Water Treatment Facility?s chlorine contact basins. Chlorine is injected into the water in order to disinfect it and to prevent bacterial growth while the water travels through pipelines. 

Chlorine leak detection and warning are provided by an alarm system. Chlorine detectors with alarms are located in the Chlorination Room. The alarms sound locally with indication lights at the City of Calexico Water Treatment Facility. The alarms also actuate a signal to the SCADA system. 



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst-Case Release Scenario 



Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined.  RMP*Comp was used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab of the Compliance Workbook. The chlorine cylinders are located in a building; therefore, this passive mitigation measure was incorporated in the calculations.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used, as specified by regulation.  



Alternative Release Scenario



A more realistic alternative release scenario was also modeled. The meteorological conditions specified by CalARP requirements for alternative release scenarios were used. RMP*Comp was used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance.  The downwind distance for this alternative release scenario is significantly less than that for the worst-case scenario. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab of the Compliance Workbook.

 

Risk Considerations



Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the Community; the City of Cal

exico Water Treatment Plant has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make this type of event non-credible.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that overpredict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a chlorine release:



1. Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) (e.g., protective clothing, escape mask) is used by plant personnel.

2. The history of the City of Calexico Water Treatment Plant (i.e., no RMP-applicable chlorine releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Chlorine System.

3. Detection and alarm systems with automatic notification.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key prevention program elements were implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine systems. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute.  In addition to the Management Programs, there are chlorine leak detectors situated in all rooms that contain chlorine.  In the event of a release the alarms sound locally with indication lights at the City of Calexico Water Treatment Facility. The alarms also actuate a signal to the SCADA System. The Prevention Program 3 elements include:



? Process Safety Information

? Process Hazard Analysis

? Operating Procedures

? Training

? Mechanical Integrity

? Management of Change

? Pre-startup Safety Review

? Compliance Audits

? Incident Investigation

? Employee Participation

? Hot Work Permit

? Contractors

? Emergency Planning & Response



The entire prevention program elements are kept in the CalARP/EPA/RMP Compliance Workbook located

onsite.  The prevention program elements satisfy the requirements of CalARP, EPA RMP, and OSHA PSM.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no EPA RMP or CalARP-applicable releases of chlorine at the facility in at least the past five (5) years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility?s employees are not first responders and are not required to have an Emergency Response Plan.  However, the facility implements an Emergency Action Plan that is kept onsite.  This plan includes:



? Reporting Procedures

? Evacuation Procedures

? Emergency Alarm Procedures

? Safety and Health Considerations

? Employee Alarm System

? Training

? Review of Emergency Action Plan



 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Several studies have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  These studies include the following: Process Hazard Analysis, Seismic Assessment, and Hazard Assessment. The planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in these reports.  Any outstanding recommendations from these studies will be addressed by December 2007.  

ADDITIONAL COMMENTS

This is a new submission; therefore a Compliance Audit has not been completed yet. There also have been no incidents at the facility therefore there are none reported. A Pre-Startup Safety Review also has not been completed; the system was in place prior to the CalARP Program being implemented. Also since this is a new program there has yet to be a review of the contractor safety.  Also, the City of Calexico Water Treatment Plant has not been inspected by a safety agency. Training on the ER plan has not been conducted.
